title: Protocols for endothelial cell isolation from mouse tissues: small intestine, colon, heart, and liver

Step-by-step method details
Small intestine endothelial cell isolation
Timing: ∼6 h 30 min
For preparation of small intestine digestion buffer Timing: 45 min
For dissection and preparation of intestine tissue for enzymatic digestion Timing: 2 h
For enzymatic digestion of intestine tissue Timing: 1 h
For endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads Timing: 45 min
For FACS Timing: 1–2 h
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A shows a detailed scheme of small intestine ECs isolation.

Figure 1. EC isolation from mouse small intestine
(A) Detailed scheme illustrating isolation of ECs from small intestine.
(B) Representative FACS plots for the gating strategy to sort ECs from small intestine based on sorting live/CD45-/CD31+ cells.
Preparation of small intestine digestion buffer
Right before isolation prepare small intestine digestion buffer containing:
Supplemented KnockOutTM DMEM-medium (see details in section ‘materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]’)
0.1% (w/v) collagenase I
0.25% (w/v) collagenase IV
0.25 U/mL Dispase
7.5 μg/mL DNAse I
table:files/protocols_protocol_627_4.csv
Right before isolation prepare pre-digestion buffer:
HBSS (Ca2+, Mg2+)
1.5 mM DTT
5% (v/v) FBS
5 mM EDTA
table:files/protocols_protocol_627_5.csv
Prepare cold HBSS (Ca2+, Mg2+).
Store the small intestine digestion buffer and pre-digestion buffer (freshly prepared) at 4°C until needed.
10 mL of small intestine digestion buffer suffices for 3 adult murine small intestines. 50 mL of pre-digestion buffer suffices for 1 adult murine small intestine.
Dissection and preparation of intestine tissue for enzymatic digestion
Before dissecting the small intestine perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/minute for 5 min.
Flush the fecal matter from the dissected small intestine with ice-cold HBSS using a 20 mL syringe and an elastic needle (use protecting insert from Insyte-WTM 18G 1.3 × 48 mm (BD Vialon™, Cat#381346)).
Note: Keep the samples on ice during the dissections.

Open the small intestine longitudinally.
Cut intestine into very small pieces (4 mm2) and place them in the 50 mL conical tube (1 intestine per conical tube).
Add 25 mL ice-cold pre-digestion buffer – invert 10–15 times, then incubate with 37°C water bath for 20 min.
Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5 min.
Vortex for 10 seconds.
Filter the content of the conical tube through a 100 μm cell strainer.
Collect undigested intestines from the strainer and place them into a new 50 mL conical tube containing 20 mL of pre-digestion buffer and incubate at 37°C water bath for 20 min. Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5 min.
Vortex for 10 seconds.
Filter the content of the conical tube through a 100 μm cell strainer.
Collect undigested intestines from the strainer and place them into a new 50 mL conical tube containing 20 mL of HBSS and incubate at 37°C for 20 min.
Filter the content of the tube through a 100 μm cell strainer.
Enzymatic digestion of intestine tissue
Collect undigested small intestines from the strainer and put them in the gentleMACS C tubes (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-237) containing pre-warmed at 37°C digestion buffer (3 mL per gentleMACS C tube).
Critical: Make sure the tube is closed tightly.
Place the gentleMACS C tubes in the gentleMACS™ Octo Dissociator (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-095-937). Run protocol 37C_m_LPDK_1 (pre-programmed by manufacturer).
Stop the reaction by adding 5 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Filter cell suspension through a 100 μm cell strainer to remove leftover undigested tissue fragments into the 50 mL conical tube.
Critical: Keep the pass-through suspension in the 50 mL conical tube.
Wash the strainer by rinsing it with the additional 10 mL of Wash Buffer 1. Collect the pass-through suspension to the same conical tube.

Centrifuge cells at 300 g for 10 min.
Carefully remove the supernatant.
Note: The supernatant contains chyle therefore should have a milky/cloudy appearance.
Resuspend pellet in 5 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Note: If supernatant is not clear, repeat washing step 3e.
Endothelial cell enrichment using CD31 murine MicroBeads
Resuspend the pellet in an appropriate amount of Wash Buffer 1 and add the appropriate volume of CD31 MicroBeads (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-097-418) to the suspension according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Note: We suggest to resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1, determine the cell number and follow the manufacturer's instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/cd31-microbeads-mouse.html?countryRedirected=1#gref]) i.e., for up to 1 × 107 total cells, resuspend the cells in 90 μL of Wash Buffer 1 and add 10 μL of CD31 MicroBeads. If fewer than 1 × 107 cells are available use the same volumes as indicated above. When working with higher cell numbers than 1 × 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes and total volumes accordingly.
Mix and incubate for 15 min at 4°C.
Note: Process samples fast in order to avoid non-specific binding of beads at 20°C–22°C.
Wash cells by adding 3 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C.
During the centrifugation step prepare collection tubes and LS columns (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-042-401) according to the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref[href=https://www.miltenyibiotec.com/US-en/products/ls-columns.html#gref]) i.e., place the column in the suitable magnetic separator and prepare the column by rinsing with 3 mL of Wash Buffer.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Apply the cell suspension onto the prepared LS column through a 40 μm cell strainer to remove potential cell aggregates in order to prevent clogging of the column.

Wash the LS column 3 times with 3 mL Wash Buffer 1 adding buffer each time once the column reservoir is empty.
Note: The eluent (CD31-negative fraction) from step 4f can be used to prepare controls for FACS analysis or can be discarded if not further needed.
Remove the LS column from the separator and place it onto a new 15 mL conical collection tube.
Pipette 5 mL Wash Buffer 1 onto the LS column. Immediately flush out the fraction containing the magnetically labeled cells (CD31-positive fraction) by firmly applying the plunger supplied with the column.
FACS CRUCIAL: Prepare all required controls for flow cytometry analysis beforehand i.e., unstained cell (US) control, viability control (VB), Fluorescence Minus One (FMO) control, isotype controls (optional), as well as the compensation controls (one for each fluorophore) for proper set up of the cytometer.
Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use the cells from, e.g.,: CD31-negative fraction, to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL Wash Buffer 1-based staining solution containing:
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g.,: CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g.,: CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g.,: eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain the cells for 30 min at 4°C min in the dark.

Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer 1 (based on the pellet size between 200 μL and 0.5 mL) and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD45-, CD31+ cells to collection tubes.
Note: To ensure high viability of the ECs, sort the ECs to collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401) in an Eppendorf (∼ 200 μL) or 15 mL conical tube (∼ 2 mL).
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B shows representative FACS plots and gating strategy of viable, CD45-, CD31+ small intestine ECs.

Prepare PBS-based Wash Buffer 2 containing:
3% (v/v) FBS in PBS
10 mM EDTA

Store the (freshly prepared) colon digestion buffer and Wash Buffer 2 at 4°C until they are needed.
10 mL of colon digestion buffer suffices for 3 adult murine colons.
Dissection and preparation of colon tissue for enzymatic digestion

Before dissecting the colon, perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/minute for 5 min.
Flush the fecal matter from the dissected colon using a 20 mL syringe and an elastic needle (use protecting insert from Insyte-WTM 18G 1.3 × 48 mm (BD Vialon™, Cat#381346)) with ice-cold PBS.
Note: Keep the samples on ice during the dissections.
Open the colon longitudinally.
Note: For easier manipulations you can fix the colon using pins or syringe needles at both ends.
Use a sterile scalpel blade to swiftly scrape out the mucus from the colon inner surface.
Place the colon on the Petri dish and cut it into very small pieces (as small as possible), place them into a 50 mL conical tube (3 colons/conical tube with 10 mL of colon digestion buffer).
Note: The pieces should pass through a cut P1000 tip (approx. 0.8 mm).
Rinse the Petri dish with an additional 4 mL of colon digestion buffer, and transfer cell suspension to gentleMACS C tube (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-237) using a P1000 micropipette.
Critical: Make sure the tube is closed tightly.
Digestion of colon tissue
Incubate cell suspension in gentle MACS C tube for 15 min at 37°C.
Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5 min to ensure rapid tissue dissociation.
Place tubes in gentleMACS™ Dissociator (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-235):
Run m_lung_01 protocol (pre-programmed by manufacturer).
Stop the enzymatic reaction by adding 15 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Filter the content using a 100 μm cell strainer into a 50 mL conical tube to remove larger tissue fragments and mucus.
Divide the filtered cells over two 15 mL conical tubes and centrifuge both cell suspensions at 300 g for 7 min.

Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellets in 5 mL of Wash Buffer 2.
Pool previously divided samples.
Filter the content using a 40 μm cell strainer into a new 50 mL conical tube to remove leftover tissue fragments and mucus, then transfer content to a 15 mL conical tube.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and wash the pellet with 5 mL Wash Buffer 2.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.

Store the heart digestion buffer (freshly prepared) at 4°C until it is needed.
5 mL of heart digestion buffer suffices for 3 adult murine hearts.
Dissection and digestion of heart tissue

Before dissecting the heart, perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/minute for 5 min.
Harvest the hearts and cut them with scalpel blade into small pieces (approx. 2 mm2).
Pool all pieces in a 50 mL conical tube containing 5 mL of heart digestion buffer.
Note: Keep the samples on ice during the dissections.
Incubate the sample in digestion buffer in a 37°C water bath for 25 min.
Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 5-10 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Transfer the mix into a gentleMACS C tube (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-237).
Critical: Make sure the tube is closed tightly.
Place tubes in gentleMACS™ Dissociator (Miltenyi Biotec, Cat#130-093-235):
Run protocol C (pre-programmed by manufacturer).
Pipet the cell suspension up and down using serological pipets with a decreasing tip size (e.g., 25 mL > 5 mL > 10 mL) until there are no big tissue clumps left and then stop the enzymatic reaction by adding 25 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Filter cell suspension through a 100 μm cell strainer to remove larger tissue fragments.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 7 min.
Collect supernatant into a new 50 mL conical tube and centrifuge again at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet obtained in step 12i in 5 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and filter through a 40 μm cell strainer to remove leftover tissue fragments. Wash the conical tube and the filter with an additional 4 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Resuspend pellet of obtained in step 12j in 4 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and filter the cell suspension through the 40 μm cell strainer used previously.
Pool both fractions and transfer to a 15 mL conical tube.

Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min, remove the supernatant.

Store the freshly prepared liver digestion buffer at 4°C until needed.
mL of liver digestion buffer suffices for 1 adult murine liver.
Dissection and digestion of liver tissue
Before dissecting the liver perform transcardial perfusion via the left ventricle with ice-cold PBS followed by additional perfusion with liver digestion buffer at a perfusion rate of 2 mL/minute for 5 min.
Transfer a single liver into a 50 mL conical tube containing 5 mL of liver digestion buffer.
Incubate the sample in the liver digestion buffer in a 37°C water bath for 30 min.
Shake the tube vigorously by hand every 10 min for faster tissue dissociation.
Mix the sample by pipetting up and down using a 10 mL serological pipette.

Stop the digestion by adding 8 mL of Wash Buffer 1.
Mix and filter the cell suspension through a 100 μm cell strainer to remove undigested tissue fragments.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 300 g for 7 min.
Remove the supernatant carefully with a pipette.
Repeat washing step by adding 5 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant carefully.
Critical: The supernatant should be clear after these washing steps. If the supernatant is still turbid/hazy, perform an additional washing step.

Note: We recommend to use the cells from the final step of the isolation as controls (US, VB, FMO, isotype controls). However, if the cell number is limited, one can use the cells from, e.g.,: CD31-negative fraction, to prepare the controls. For compensation controls we would recommend to use compensation beads (e.g., OneComp eBeads™ Compensation Beads, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#01-1111-41) to ensure clear fluorescence signal and sufficient compensation.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 g for 5 min and remove the supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in 0.5 mL Wash Buffer 1-based staining solution containing:
CD11b Monoclonal Antibody (M1/70), e.g.,: CD11b-PE (BioLegend, Cat#101208) (1:500).
CD31 (PECAM-1) Monoclonal Antibody (390), e.g.,: CD31-FITC (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#11-0311-82; 1:300).
CD45 Monoclonal Antibody (30-F11), e.g.,: CD45-PE-Cyanine7 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#25-0451-82; 1:700).
Viability Dye, e.g.,: eFluor 450 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#65-0863-18; 1:1000).
Stain the cells for 30 min at 4°C in the dark.
Add 3 mL of Wash Buffer 1 and centrifuge the stained cells at 300 g for 5 min at 4°C, remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in Wash Buffer 1 (based on the pellet size between 200 μL and 0.5 mL) and proceed with FACS.
Sort viable, CD11b-, and CD31+ cells to collection tubes.
Note: To ensure high viability of the ECs, sort the ECs to collection medium (10% (v/v) FBS in PBS, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cat#A38401) in an Eppendorf (∼ 200 μL) or 15 mL conical tube (∼ 2 mL).
